utterances.speaker: CARLSON

utterances.speaker: GALLAGHER

utterances.speaker: NICOLLE WALLACE, MSNBC HOST

utterances.speaker: JOHN BRENNAN, FORMER DIRECTOR OF THE CIA

utterances.speaker: SCOTT WAPNER, CNBC HOST

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, as of this moment, though, nobody is planning to vote for Mark Cuban. A lot of people though seem to be backing Joe Biden. He is leading the Democratic field and it's not even close. He is way ahead of everybody else. The question is, will Biden's candidacy survive a year-long campaign? Already, he is not making much sense. Yesterday, he answered a pretty simple question about China with the verbal equivalent of abstract art. It was just bizarre. Today, Biden endorsed a supporter who called the President an illegitimate Putin puppet. Watch this. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, D-PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Dana Perino hosts "The Daily Briefing with Dana Perino," one of our favorite people. She joins us tonight. So Dana, everybody assumes that -- two things -- one, that Biden is kind of the adult in the field. He is the most moderate, sensible, instinctively centrist candidate. I'm not sure that's true. And they also assume that he is at the top of his game and he can persist for a full year. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: So I've got a couple of things. He does have something, right? So there's name ID. Okay, name ID accounts for a lot, especially at this stage. But it's not just name ID because they -- you know, Bernie and those guys, they tried to attack him early on, on all of his problems of touching women inappropriately, didn't put a dent in his poll numbers. In fact, Biden's numbers with women have gone up since he has entered the race. The other thing that he may be has is that electability question like Democrats, their main concern, as you heard the woman just say to Biden is she can't take another six years of Trump. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } It's actually only going to be four, you know how those things work, but I see her point, she is counting today, but the President is not going to be impeached before the election.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Good point.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So with Biden, you see something though, like, for example, the Gallup poll today shows his favorability way ahead against other Democrats. But the Quinnipiac poll just came out right before I came up here and it shows him against Trump in Pennsylvania 58 to 38. Okay, so there's something there. And I think that if you trust the President, President Trump and his political instincts, who has he been going after the most recently? And it's been Biden, because I think that he has this instinct, he knows that people think that. It doesn't mean that there aren't vulnerabilities for Biden, and we can talk about those. But I do think that the President's instincts are correct on this.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Interesting. So unless my math is off, just doing it in my head now, I think Biden, if he were to win would be older on inauguration day than Reagan was when he left after eight years.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right. So again, and now the general population when they go -- when they vote in a general election, if it does end up being Biden versus Trump, will they calculate that in? Probably. Maybe. I mean, Biden might say, "Well, look, I'm six years older than this guy who I am running against, but you know, there is an energy level that's different and it's obvious." if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } Now, some people in the Democratic side might say, "We like Biden's energy. We like the calm." A lot of other people are like, "Well, wait, we want the energy," and you and I work with a lot of people who are in their 70s and are kicking rear end and doing well.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: We just had what on the set here -- smarter than I am. Brit Hume.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Exactly. Exactly.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: For sure.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And so, I do think, though, that he is vulnerable on a couple of things. One, he started reacting to Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio- Cortez, right because she's needling him. I would ignore her if I were the Biden candidate, but he is going back at her. I think it doesn't look right. I also think that the opponents are playing nice right now. Okay. Everybody is like being nice, everybody is nice. They're going to start attacking him. He hasn't faced one negative ad. But you started to see for today, Kamala Harris, what did she do? utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Man, I'm skeptical. But --

utterances.sentences: I know -- a lot -- and I talked to somebody who thinks that there's no way you can be the front runner for 16 months and pull this off.

utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.sentences: And something -- we all know, something is going to happen. We don't know what it is.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You've got 21 other people in the race. Dana Perino, you should get in.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Can I say one last thing?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Happy Birthday Eve from Ingrid and me.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You're sweet. Thank you. I am ignoring it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Have a good one.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But I appreciate that. Thank you. Well, Seattle is home to Jeff Bezos and Bill Gates, two of the richest men on the planet. But it's also home to countless people living on the streets -- a massive homeless population. How did that happen? We're taking a close look as our next installment of "Homeless in America" continues after the break.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Maybe more than any other city, Seattle, Washington seems to represent what America is becoming. Amazon, Microsoft, Starbucks are all based in the city or its suburbs. Jeff Bezos, the richest man in the world lives there. But along with unfathomable wealth, there is also desperate poverty and widespread degradation. Seattle's homeless population is surging. The city is suffocating under garbage produced by hundreds of homeless camps. Rather than take action, the City Council has enabled the problem and even recently suggested that garbage is really left by middle class residents who are trying to frame the homeless. Local news broadcast recently grabbed national headlines by worrying that Seattle is dying, the city becomes unlivable for regular families. For day three of our "Homeless in America" series, our producer Charlie Cougar visited Seattle to get an up close look at what is happening there. Seattle's homelessness crisis is deeply connected to the city's drug crisis. That's what we learned when we visited this sprawling encampment off of Interstate-5.

utterances.speaker: ERIC NELSON, HOMELESS
utterances.sentences: It's really sad.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Washington native, Eric Nelson is homeless. He lives in a nearby shelter. But he is undergoing methadone treatment. He came to this encampment to visit friends.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Do you think drugs are one of the primary drivers of homelessness?

utterances.speaker: NELSON
utterances.sentences: I think mental health is. Mental health is the foundation of you know, a lot of you know, addiction and other things.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Mental health and addiction are clearly problems. When we arrived on a Wednesday afternoon, the residents were cleaning up their camp. It was littered with syringes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: How many people would you say, like as a percentage from living out here are doing drugs?

utterances.speaker: NELSON
utterances.sentences: I would say a good 60 percent. You know, that's maybe a little short, but benefited out, you know.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: How easy is it go get heroin?

utterances.speaker: NELSON
utterances.sentences: Really -- it's really easy.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Even outside the I-5 five camp, there was evidence of a drug epidemic throughout Seattle. Near a shelter downtown, we found this poster warning drug users about the dangers of fentanyl. Seattle is a kind of Mecca for drug addicts. Washington State legalized marijuana and Seattle's police force has a program that refers some low level drug criminals to social services instead of jail. Like San Francisco, Seattle City government has essentially decriminalized quality of life crimes. Misdemeanor citations have plummeted since 2009. The consequence? Well, see it for yourself. Here's a video of a man passed out in a popular park. This picture shows urine on a public staircase near City Hall. This picture shows human waste a few steps above that. Homelessness became more visible as Seattle's leaders became more lenient on petty crime. Because of their liberal attitudes and the mild climate, the city as a magnet for vagrants. Nelson thinks most of the people at the I-5 camp didn't grow up in the area.

utterances.speaker: NELSON
utterances.sentences: Probably about more than half are probably not from Seattle.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Homelessness is complicated. Drugs aren't the only cause. Take a look at this picture of people living in broken down RVs. In the background, the world headquarters of Starbucks. Like most of the West Coast, Seattle's economic boom has not been distributed evenly, not close. When wages at the low end of the economic spectrum fail to keep up with the rising cost of living, you wind up with a place where people living in their cars are flanked by billionaires like Jeff Bezos and Bill Gates. So what causes homelessness? Many things -- drug addiction, economic hardship, illness -- but one thing that everyone living on the street seems to have in common, broken families. In the case of Eric Nelson, he hasn't seen his family since he was 16 years old.

utterances.speaker: NELSON
utterances.sentences: We just kind of split. We didn't really have too much in common so I just parted ways when I was 16. And then, I ran out of money. I ran out of everything and so I was homeless.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It isn't just big city suffering from the homelessness epidemic. Tomorrow night, as our series continues, we'll take a look at homelessness in the college town of Eugene, Oregon. Amazing what's happening there? Well, Bernie Sanders and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez are pushing a cap on credit card interest rates and also a cap on payday loan rates. So why are conservatives letting left-wing demagogues beat them at protecting consumers? Something that virtually all voters are for. That's just ahead. Plus Beto O'Rourke has a new tactic for turning around his flagging presidential campaign. We'll tell you what it is.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Tuesday was a tough day for Beto O'Rourke. First day to go in "The View" and apologized for his white privilege and he groveled for the crime of appearing on a magazine cover. It wasn't fun running for President, it isn't very fun most of the time. Certainly, less fun than writing blog posts about your road trip across America, eating at diners, riding your skateboard. Beto needs to get the fun back in his life. So today he decided there's only one way to do that -- give the world more Beto. Take a swim in the Lake Me. Narcissism on parade. So he went over to have haircut and decided to livestream the whole thing on Facebook as you do. Beto even talked about cutting his ear hair as it progressed, watch.

utterances.speaker: BETO O'ROURKE, D-PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: Cutting out some of this ear hair that you get when you get older. It grows out of your ears and if you don't get it cut, it could be nasty.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You'd have to think you're pretty interesting to want to show people that. Does America agree? We'll find out. Good luck, Beto. Well, Senator Bernie and Congresswoman Ocasio-Cortez have introduced a bill that would cap credit card and payday loan interest at 15% a year. The only obvious question is why didn't Republicans introduced this bill? It's not their voters are against it. They're totally for it. A new poll by Business Insider finds that 70 percent of both parties support this proposal. So is there any reason not to pass it right now? Thomas Vartanian is a Professor at George Mason's Antonin Scalia Law School. He is Executive Director of the school's Program of Financial Regulation and Technology. Right in the middle of this issue all the time. So we're grateful that he can join us tonight. Professor, thanks very much for coming on.

utterances.speaker: THOMAS VARTANIAN, PROFESSOR, GEORGE MASON'S ANTONIN SCALIA LAW SCHOOL
utterances.sentences: Great to be here, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So why do you think 70 percent of Republicans would support this?

utterances.speaker: VARTANIAN
utterances.sentences: You know, I don't know because history is replete with problems that have occurred from rate controls and tinkering with pieces of the market, because it forces certain things to happen in other parts of the market.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: VARTANIAN
utterances.sentences: So for example, we put a 15 percent rate control on, there's no doubt that consumers deserve the best services they can get at the fairest price. But when you put a rate control on, what you are effectively doing is shrinking the credit pool. And guess who gets kicked out of that credit pool when it gets smaller? The people who need the credit the most. So that's the problem with --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, I agree. I mean, I certainly agree that there are always unintended consequences to these things, and you can't tamper in markets without changing outcomes you didn't intend to change, no question about that. But credit card debt in the United States is a trillion dollars. The average family with credit card debt owes $15,000.00, and they're paying an average of 21 percent interest on that. That's a disaster. So why would it make us sad to stop that?

utterances.speaker: VARTANIAN
utterances.sentences: Well, the problem is that not everybody is paying 21 percent. Twenty one percent is the median and that's a little bit deceptive, all right. If you go online today, you can find credit cards at eight and a half percent. You can find credit cards being offered by hundreds of different credit card companies. So you can argue that the market is not competitive.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, you can also find in the mid-36 percent. But the point is the median is still 21, which is multiples -- many multiples of what you could borrow money from a bank and for whatever reason, this is working for the banks, that's when they made $170 billion in interest and fees last year on it. So again, why would it be bad to reduce the outstanding credit card debt in the country?

utterances.speaker: VARTANIAN
utterances.sentences: The reason it would be bad is because it would take away credit from the people who need it the most. It's not the way to go after that problem. I think there are other better ways of dealing with that problem. But when you shrink the credit base, the people with the lowest credit ratings and the worst credit history are going to lose their access to credit. Bobby Kennedy wrote a letter in 1964 to the New York state legislator after he had done all that work, investigating organized crime, and he asked him to eliminate usury rates in New York, because it was the one thing that was forcing people to go to loan sharks because couldn't get legitimate credit.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I think that's probably right. But in 1960, or whenever, there's no doubt that Americans were less in debt, less enslaved by debt than they are now. And so why is it bad to say maybe we should all try -- rich and poor -- among us to live within our own means a little bit, and going into debt is actually not freedom. It's the opposite of freedom. Why wouldn't we say that?

utterances.speaker: VARTANIAN
utterances.sentences: That is absolutely correct. Americans are in too much debt. There's no doubt about it. But the way to go about dealing with that debt is through financial literacy. The financial literacy rate in this country is abominably abysmal.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Really? So if you're paying 391 percent interest, that's what -- that's the average interest in payday loans, okay. You don't need to be financially literate to know you're getting totally shafted, and yet millions of people do that anyway.

utterances.speaker: VARTANIAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, no, I don't think it's --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Why wouldn't you stop that? I mean, people are really being abused and taken advantage of?

utterances.speaker: VARTANIAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, well, look, I think the abuses need to be taken care of, but we're not talking about abuses here in terms of this 15 percent limitation, you're talking about changing the markets in the country dramatically.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, I am.

utterances.speaker: VARTANIAN
utterances.sentences: Right. And it's -- so the abuses need to be dealt with. But you don't deal with an abuse by capping everybody's interest rate and saying to everybody who is following the law, who is dealing with their customers fairly, "We're going to put you in a bind," because when you put them in a bind, they're going to put their customers in a bind.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, I would do it anyway. Just like I wouldn't let people sell their kidneys or their children in slavery.

utterances.speaker: VARTANIAN
utterances.sentences: Well, the last -- the last time we did something like that, of course is the savings and loan crisis. So I think when you tinker with the market, you have to be ready for the consequences.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, right. Well, this would be one good consequence. Professor, thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: VARTANIAN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I appreciate it. The U.S. government announced today that is pulling all nonemergency staff out of the American Embassy in Iraq, as well as our consulate in Erbil there. They're getting evacuated and it's in response to a possible attack that we're being told is being plotted by Iranian-backed forces of some kind in the region. In any case, it is the latest escalation of tension there. The U.S. has already deployed a Carrier Battle Group to the Persian Gulf. The "New York Times" says the President is presented with a plan to deploy up to 120,000 American troops for potential military action against Iran. Iran is also tonight being blamed for a sabotage attack on several Saudi ships docked in the UAE, though so far that link has not been proven. As the "Onion" said today, an attack on the Saudi tanker is an attack on America, which basically is the case they're making in Washington. Every day, we seem to get closer to a conflict with Iran. Before that actually happens, we'd like at least one question answered -- what critical American interest would going to war with Iran serve? No one has even bothered to address that question. Hopefully somebody will. We will keep on it. Well, Ed Henry, our friend has a new book coming out. He is here to reveal what it's about. He is doing that exclusively on the show, not to brag -- one hint, it's about baseball. That's next.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Time now for an intermittent segment we call "The Friend Zone" where we invite one of our actual friends from Fox onto the show. When he is not serving as Fox's chief national correspondent, Ed Henry writes and reads books. He has already written one about Jackie Robinson, and he's here tonight exclusively to reveal the theme of his next book, Ed Henry.

utterances.speaker: ED HENRY, CHIEF NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: I've been waiting -- I'm so excited about this and I'm waiting to do this -- hang on, actually. Okay, actually, we have a Fox News Alert. I'm going to hold off on the book. We've got some breaking news. It is Tucker's birthday. And this was an elaborate hoax. I'm not writing a new book. But I'm bringing in a couple of our good friends to help celebrate.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, I was not aware of this at all. Thank you. I'm glad were live. Oh, what are you doing here?

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: They wanted to tell stories about you. It's kind of a roast.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, this is so nice.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: I don't have any.

utterances.speaker: LAURA INGRAHAM, HOST
utterances.sentences: Your cake is covered in wax. I think it's been lit --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Of course if I had known this is going to happen -- thank you, Louie. That's amazing.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: It's a big one.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: And you actually have the right number on there. Oh, Emily.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Blow it out before -- oh my gosh, look at all. Just think --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I'm trying -- I'm trying to take this in good humor. I can't believe you did this. Is this actually on TV?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Fifty is good for a fine Bordeaux, you're just getting into your prime now.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: Tucker, I can say that at the age of 50, you've got everything you need for your career going forward, because you have all your hair and as far as I can tell, most of your teeth.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: And it's mostly real.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: And half of your wit.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It's mostly real. And actually my wits are in great decline. I'm not as fast as I used to be. By the way, I had literally no idea this was happening. And I said to our beloved Emily Lynn, whatever you do, I don't want you to acknowledge my birthday in any way, which is actually tomorrow because it's so depressing. And I've spent all day brooding about mortality.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: You look --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Until I talked to Britt who said, "Wow, 50 is not a big deal. Wait until you get to be 75." I was like, "Yes, you're right. I am whining."

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Can I talk about the impact you've had all around the world.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes -- all around the world. Yes, you may.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: So I was in Scottsdale yesterday for this Fox Nation, so we had a great time with over a thousand of our viewers who came out. And they were waiting out in the heat. So I went out there with John Finley, one of our bosses and we were handing out water. We were taking pictures, shaking hands, and Erik Wemple of The Washington Post" was there. And he wanted to do a story on it. And you've made him famous with this mug. I don't know if we can -- and this is the best part. People in the crowd -- let me hold it up. They recognized Erik Wemple.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: From the mug?

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: From the mug. They were like, "You're that guy on Tucker's mug."

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: That's all he's accomplished in 50 years?

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: That's about -- that's what Tucker -- and here is the thing, they were like, "You look better in person." And so to Erik's credit, he wrote a story about it.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: ... the picture on the mug?

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's pretty rough.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It was not his best moment, I am glad we commemorated it. I don't know. Making Erik Wemple famous, maybe that's not much of a legacy, I am starting to think. Actually, you made me feel a little sad.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry. Maybe I made it worse.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I am getting older.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: You still have time, Tucker. That's just one small --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Tucker, you've not -- I've known you for 20 something years.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Many years.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Doing events with you and all the kind of -- and Tucker is literally one of the people who never ages. He looks the same. You never age so you don't have to worry. The rep tie -- I mean, you've had that since what?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, many years. Well, I used to have rep bowties, but I gave those up.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Yes, and we got you a birthday cake flavored vape, you know, vaping pen, so --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I've totally given that up.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Oh, shucks, well --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: For my 50th birthday, I got off the Nicorette. And that's what - -

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: Did you really?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I really did.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: He had to quit it.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: After 36 years, I got off it.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: How long ago did you do that?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I did it one month and three days ago.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: And do you still ever -- is there a chaw in your cheek every now and then?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Not a chaw. I gave it up. No tobacco of any kind.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: No tobacco of any kind? How long has this been going on?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, for 36 years.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: No, I'm talking about abstinence.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It's gone on -- abstinence has gone on for one month and three days.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: How do you feel?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I feel honestly like the contents of my head have been emptied. Yes, I feel --

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: You don't feel noticeably --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I feel like an untethered balloon actually floating above looking down.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: You remember that time not too many months and years ago when you were with CNN and there was the embarrassment about the phone number.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I do remember that.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: And you came over to the -- you came over to the Bureau to chat --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You're the only person who remembers that. This was 2001 or 2002. I was hosting a show at CNN. And as a joke, I gave out the Fox News Bureau number on air.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: On the air, yes, on the air. And Fox News, which always hits harder came back, gave out my home phone number on its air. Yes. And so I stormed over to the Fox News Bureau. By the way, I've worked at Fox News for 10 years today, which is amazing.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: Congratulations.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Many years ago, and I stormed over there and I ran into James Rose and I said I want to get in there and tell him what I think, and I saw Brit who I lived across the street from Georgetown as a kid and really respected and Brit Hume comes out and says, "Tucker, I don't think you can win this one. Maybe you should just give it a rest." Then I walked back to the CNN Bureau with my tail between my legs.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: Well, you said that -- you said at the time that you were afraid of Roger Ailes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I was afraid of Roger Ailes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: Who ended up hiring you, right?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Who I wound up loving, he is really a great and wise man.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Tucker is one of the -- well, we have a lot of great people at Fox who support what women are trying to do and advancement of young careers. But Tucker is actually one of the people, Brit, you're another, okay, Ed, you're fine.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Okay. I'm all right.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: But Tucker and I, and we do the primetime thing. And so we hit hard and we're also targets. There are a few people I'd rather be in a foxhole with taking the shots than Tucker Carlson because we're just like, it's like incoming. It's like bing, bing, bing, bing and we deal with it every day and it's just -- you've been a great help to me and a great inspiration and I want to thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, thank you.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Even though we don't -- we don't hang out. It's like we don't hang out. Tucker in the hallway is like, "Laura Ingraham," and then he just walks by. I'm like, "Hey, that's Tucker." "Laura Ingraham, Raymond Arroyo." He just yells your name and --

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: And he always actually -- I think that he is delighted that he recognized you.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Right. It's like "Whoa."

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: And then he lets out that laugh.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm deep in space. That's -- no, but we spend a lot of time texting.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: We do. We talk. We talk a lot offline and you've been -- you've been a great help and it's such a great addition to this network across the board.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, thank you. Would you -- I just have to ask in closing, Brit Hume, would you have any advice for a man entering this stage of life? This is a -- I'm asking you this question cold. So if you have no good advice, it's okay.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: All I can say is longevity is tough in this business.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: Hair and teeth are important.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: So go to the dentist, right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Brush and comb.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: Brush and comb. Go to the dentist, right. Keep your health. Don't get fat, right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: That's a tough one.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: It is a tough one.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It is a tough one.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: And go to the gym.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, off, nicotine, getting birthday cakes. Yes, it's tough.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: There you go. There you go. And keep on doing what you're doing.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Climb back on the Stairmaster tomorrow. How long do you -- I am not going to ask you any age-related question.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: How long do you have to go until 50?

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Two more after this July.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Would you offer any advice? A man on the on the lower end of it looking up?

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: I like the teeth idea. I didn't think about that because -- I think about the hair, but the teeth. I think Brit is absolutely right and don't eat that cake.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Tucker, don't become one of those old people who just talks about their ailments because if you sit around the table and you start getting into that conversation --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I would never.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: I have a goiter --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I would literally never do that.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.sentences: The organ recital bit.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Yes, we don't need to hear about that.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: But you're the original happy warrior and I think that came across.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, I am a happy person. And by the way, if I had a goiter, I would never mention it.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: We were going to be --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I would pretend it wasn't even there.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: We were going to be smug and pomposity tonight with a t-shirt, but we didn't have time to print them up.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Happy birthday.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Thank you, guys. I appreciate. Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: For the next --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: All right, we're out of time. That was weird and great. We will be back tomorrow night, 8:00 p.m. The show that is the sworn enemy of lying, pomposity, smugness and especially groupthink which is in oversupply in Washington as it is probably everywhere. Anyway, thanks for joining us tonight. Good night from Washington. We have a special surprise, untapped for the 9:00 p.m. hour and for the whole duration, by the way.
